title: torch.random — PyTorch 2.9 documentation
text:
## torch.random#

Created On: Aug 07, 2019 | Last Updated On: Jun 18, 2025
Forks the RNG, so that when you return, the RNG is reset
to the state that it was previously in.
devices(iterableofDevice IDs) – devices for which to fork
the RNG. CPU RNG state is always forked. By default,fork_rng()operates
on all devices, but will emit a warning if your machine has a lot
of devices, since this function will run very slowly in that case.
If you explicitly specify devices, this warning will be suppressed
fork_rng()
enabled(bool) – ifFalse, the RNG is not forked.  This is a convenience
argument for easily disabling the context manager without having
to delete it and unindent your Python code under it.
False
device_type(str) – device type str, default iscuda. As for supported device,
see details inaccelerator
Generator
Returns the random number generator state as atorch.ByteTensor.
Note
The returned state is for the default generator on CPU only.
See also:torch.random.fork_rng().
torch.random.fork_rng()
Tensor
Returns the initial seed for generating random numbers as a
Pythonlong.
Note
The returned seed is for the default generator on CPU only.
int
Sets the seed for generating random numbers on all devices. Returns atorch.Generatorobject.
seed(int) – The desired seed. Value must be within the inclusive range[-0x8000_0000_0000_0000, 0xffff_ffff_ffff_ffff]. Otherwise, a RuntimeError
is raised. Negative inputs are remapped to positive values with the formula0xffff_ffff_ffff_ffff + seed.
Generator

Sets the seed for generating random numbers to a non-deterministic
random number on all devices. Returns a 64 bit number used to seed the RNG.
int
Sets the random number generator state.
Note
This function only works for CPU. For CUDA, please usetorch.manual_seed(), which works for both CPU and CUDA.
torch.manual_seed()
new_state(torch.ByteTensor) – The desired state
